node.title: Corporate Climate Pledges Often Ignore a Key Component: Supply Chains
node.description: Many companies do not account for the emissions from their supply chains, which can be a significant majority of their contributions to greenhouse gases.

node.title: As U.S. Reopening Approaches, Travelers Take Their Marks
node.description: The end of the U.S. ban on international visitors has kicked off a surge in travel both foreign and domestic. Here’s what to expect for the holiday season and beyond.

node.title: How Greek Islands Are Labs for Clean Energy
node.description: Many Greek islands are being used for innovative experiments to drive the clean power shift.

node.title: The Supreme Court Might Claim Power Over Gun Carry Laws. That Would Be a Mistake.
node.description: The court shouldn’t take from the people and their legislatures the authority they have had for centuries to decide where handguns may be carried.

node.title: What Makes Change Possible?
node.description: The failures of the Articles of Confederation have a lot to teach us about the conditions that make new forms of government feasible.

node.title: The Life-Altering Differences Between White and Black Debt
node.description: The sociologist Louise Seamster discusses America’s student debt crisis and how higher education contributes to the racial wealth gap.

node.title: Shutting Down Historical Debate, China Makes It a Crime to Mock Heroes
node.description: Under a new law, China has zealously prosecuted even the perceived slander of Communist figures, broadening Xi Jinping’s campaign to dominate party orthodoxy.

node.title: Newt Gingrich Says Democrats Will 'Steal' Virginia if Governor Election is Close
node.description: The former House speaker attempted to cast doubt on a legitimate victory for Democratic candidate Terry McAuliffe ahead of Tuesday's vote.

node.title: How will Macron's 'liar' claim play out with Morrison's voters?
node.description: Scott Morrison's spat with the French President is bad for his international reputation. But on the home front, the PM will reckon on neutralising Emmanuel Macron's allegation,  writes Michelle Grattan.

node.title: Search underway after fisherman falls out of tinnie into Queensland dam
node.description: Specialist divers have been dispatched to help look for the man, who fell out of his boat earlier today.

node.title: Queen Elizabeth, calling for statesmanship, not politics, said ‘the time for action’ is now.
node.description: The 95-year-old monarch gave her address by video, after doctors advised her to rest and not go to the summit. Prince Charles attended and delivered a similar message.

node.title: White House in major push to cut methane emissions
node.description: The centerpiece is new rules for the oil and gas sector, the biggest industrial source of methane, is a potent greenhouse gas and climate change contributor

node.title: Still Unvaccinated, and Now on Unpaid Leave
node.description: About 9,000 city workers did not comply with a new vaccine mandate, but Mayor Bill de Blasio said the first day went smoothly.

node.title: Cryptocurrency inspired by ‘Squid Game’ crashes. The industry has questions.
node.description: The digital money, called Squid, began trading last week for a penny. It soared, spectacularly, before the money vanished.

node.title: Unexplained gas funding timeline a 'very dark day for the Commonwealth', Federal Court judge says
node.description: Lawyers for environmental advocates question whether the federal government fast-tracked an agreement to provide funding to a gas company in a bid to hinder legal action challenging the grant.

node.title: Elon Musk says he'll donate billions to fight world hunger, but only if a UN agency meets his conditions
node.description: Elon Musk, the world's richest person, says he will donate $US6 billion to the UN's initiative to address world hunger if the global body can meet his terms around transparency and accounting.

node.title: 'New number one strategic risk is Covid endemic' - Southern DHB
node.description: The worst case scenario modelling for Southern DHB painted a grim picture for a health system already under pressure.

node.title: Police continue to search for Raglan fishermen
node.description: Police are using a drone and the Eagle helicopter to search for two men who went gone missing after fishing near Raglan on Sunday.

node.title: Nigeria building collapse: At least four killed in Lagos
node.description: At least four people have died and dozens are missing after a high-rise block collapsed during construction in the Nigerian city of Lagos.

node.title: Auckland stays in level 3 step 1, parts of Waikato move to level 3 step 2
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says Cabinet has decided in principle to move Auckland to alert level 3 step 2 next Tuesday at 11.59pm.

node.title: COP26 summit: Leaders strike deal to end deforestation by 2030
node.description: A major deforestation deal has been announced at the end of COP26's first day of the leaders' summit where big polluters made new commitments, but with substantial caveats.

node.title: As Earth Warms, Human History Is Melting Away
node.description: Climate change is revealing long-frozen artifacts and animals to archaeologists. But the window for study is slender and shrinking.

node.title: How Car Shortages Are Putting the World’s Economy at Risk
node.description: Because so many jobs depend on automaking, the industry’s production problems are causing the pain to ripple.

node.title: Pharmacist fined for incorrectly dispensing drugs
node.description: An Auckland pharmacist has been found guilty of professional misconduct for the incorrect dispensing of drugs.

node.title: Trump Told Georgia Secretary of State He Believed States Would Be 'Flipping' to Him After Election
node.description: Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger dismissed Trump's claims that the size of his rallies showed he couldn't have lost the 2020 presidential election.

node.title: Data, other intangible assets to drive company growth - research
node.description: Intangible asset specialist EverEdge says such assets can grow much faster, which is good news for companies with business models built around data.

node.title: 'We won't enforce discrimination' - Gym owners shut shop over vaccine mandates
node.description: A West Coast couple have chosen to close their gym, instead of turning away customers who are not vaccinated.

node.title: Stephen Colbert: Biden Got the Pope’s Blessing
node.description: “The pope telling you you’re a good Catholic is like a bear telling you you’re good at pooping in the woods,” Colbert said of President Biden, who visited the Vatican over the weekend.

node.title: PM makes each-way bet on climate change at COP26
node.description: While Australians put their money on horses today, Scott Morrison had a wager of his own: An each-way bet that $20 billion in technological investments will either fix the climate crisis, or at least convince other nations Australia is doing enough.

node.title: Little risk of contamination after fire at sewage treatment plant - council
node.description: Christchurch City Council is reassuring residents there is little risk of beaches becoming contaminated with untreated waste.

node.title: Police deny media spotlight led to man being allowed into WA to see sick mum
node.description: A man who made it through WA's hard border to see his sick mother commends the WA Government for wanting to keep people safe, but says he's shocked at the process he had to go through to make it home to Perth.

node.title: 'Shocked and saddened': Alec Baldwin's assistant director calls for reform
node.description: Rust assistant director David Halls releases a statement to the New York Post,  saying he's shocked and saddened by the October 21 death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins in New Mexico, saying the industry must "reevaluate its values and practices".

node.title: World leaders agree to stop deforestation by 2030
node.description: More than 100 leaders representing more than 85 per cent of the world's forests agree to end logging but environmental activists are calling for swifter action.

node.title: Covid-19 updates: Auckland inmates among positive cases
node.description: A small number of Covid-19 cases in Corrections custody in Auckland have been reported by the Ministry of Health.

node.title: Man accused of killing Elizabeth Zhong named
node.description: The man accused of murdering Auckland businesswoman Elizabeth Zhong can now be named.

node.title: Water discharging into sea not up to standard after treatment plant fire
node.description: Christchurch City Council says it is confident it can still do a "pretty good job" of treating sewage at the plant.

node.title: Flemington Racecourse welcomes back thousands of punters, fans for Melbourne Cup
node.description: The roses are in bloom, luxury dining precincts are stocked with champagne and the lawns will soon be scattered with punters as Flemington Racecourse welcomes back 10,000 revellers for the 2021…

node.title: New 'navigator' to reduce meth harm on the West Coast
node.description: A new 'navigator' role has been created on the West Coast to support people impacted by methamphetamine, police say.

node.title: Nine arrested, drugs and firearms seized in Timaru
node.description: Nine people have been charged with drug and firearm offences after police executed 10 search warrants in Timaru over the past three days.

node.title: France's President is calling Scott Morrison a liar. How did we get here?
node.description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has been called a liar by French President Emmanuel Macron while on the international stage. But did Mr Morrison mislead the French over his intentions on the submarine deal, or was the arrangement already dead in the water?

node.title: At least $38b in JobKeeper went to companies where turnover did not fall sufficiently
node.description: Analysis by the federal Parliamentary Budget Office found that $38 billion in JobKeeper payments went to employers that did not suffer sustained downturns below threshold levels.

node.title: Appeal over legality of 2020 Covid-19 lockdown dismissed
node.description: The Court of Appeal has dismissed private court action taken over the legality of last year's Covid-19 alert level 4 lockdown.

node.title: Anti-money laundering compliance firm rakes in $30m
node.description: A local anti-money laundering compliance firm has received strong backing from overseas investors, amid growing scrutiny on global tax havens and money laundering.

node.title: Biden Administration Moves to Limit Methane, a Potent Greenhouse Gas
node.description: A new rule will be announced at a U.N. summit where the United States is facing skepticism about its commitment to climate change, aides said.

node.title: Women's and Children's Hospital reveals number of unvaccinated staff, protesters gather in Adelaide CBD
node.description: The CEO of Adelaide's Women's and Children's Hospital reveals 133 staff have refused to be vaccinated against COVID-19 and have been forced to take leave. Meanwhile, dozens of anti-mandatory vaccination protesters rally in the CBD.

node.title: Georgia Secretary of State Says GOP Didn't 'Read the Tea Leaves' Ahead of Trump 2020 Loss
node.description: Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger blamed Republicans for assuming Trump would win the election despite signs pointing to it being a close race.

node.title: What caused Hobart's spooky Halloween sunset?
node.description: Trick or treaters across Hobart on Sunday saw an eerie sight in the evening sky that mirrored the spooky streets below. But the answer to what caused the strange clouds is fairly straightforward.

node.title: Incentivise red hot favourite for Melbourne Cup
node.description: Australian-bred stayer Incentivise will look to cap a golden spring with victory in the $8.4 million Melbourne Cup today as the runaway favourite in "the race that stops the nation".

node.title: Second man arrested following Auckland Domain gathering on Saturday
node.description: Police have arrested and charged a 57-year-old man with Failing to Comply with Order (Covid-19) over the event.

node.title: Former Ireland coach Joe Schmidt joins Blues for Super Ruby 2022
node.description: The former Ireland coach, New Zealander Joe Schmidt, will join the Blues coaching staff in a support role for the 2022 Super Rugby season.

node.title: Man who allegedly set ex-partner on fire likely used accelerant, court told
node.description: Medical experts have given evidence in the attempted murder trial of a man who allegedly set his partner alight, saying the pattern of her burns indicates an accelerant was used.

node.title: Ho ho ho turns to no no no as Queensland restrictions slay Santa bookings
node.description: A Santa hire business has copped a near 80 per cent drop in bookings as Queensland's COVID restrictions cast a pall over the holiday season.

node.title: Councillor calls for review of children's books about racism, gender identity
node.description: Anti-racism and LGBTQIA+ campaigners reject a Toowoomba councillor's calls to remove children's books discussing discrimination from library shelves.

node.title: Verry Elleegant secures the biggest win of her career, winning the Melbourne Cup
node.description: Despite never winning beyond 2400m going into the race, Verry Elleegant has secured the biggest win of her career with Melbourne Cup glory at Flemington.

node.title: Researcher refuses vaccines because he's had a dose of his own COVID-19 jab
node.description: An Adelaide medical researcher who has developed and been administered with his own COVID-19 vaccine says he is facing the sack because of his refusal to get one of the TGA-approved jabs.

node.title: Covid-19: 126 new community cases today
node.description: The Ministry of Health says of the 126 new community cases, 107 are in Auckland, 18 in Waikato, and one in Northland.

node.title: Here’s What to Watch in New York and New Jersey Elections
node.description: New York City will elect three citywide positions, while both the governor’s race in New Jersey and the mayor’s race in Buffalo could have national implications.

node.title: What to Watch in Tuesday’s Elections: Virginia, Mayor’s Races and Policing
node.description: The Virginia governor’s race will be closely studied for clues about the midterms, and new mayors will be chosen in New York, Boston, Buffalo, Atlanta and more.

node.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
node.description: Old divides at a major climate summit.

node.title: COP26: Modi says India targets net zero emissions by 2070
node.description: India's prime minister used the COP26 climate talks to announce 2070 as the target for his country to reach net zero carbon emissions, two decades beyond what scientists say is needed to avert…

node.title: Bold fashion under blue skies at Flemington as crowds welcomed back for Melbourne Cup
node.description: For the first time since the COVID-19 pandemic began, thousands of Melbourne Cup fans descend on Flemington to watch in person the race that stops a nation.

node.title: While Australia throws open its international borders, WA residents watch from the sidelines
node.description: As international flights resume in other parts of the nation, West Australians are having to be patient, but the rumblings of discontent with the state's hard border stance are growing, writes Andrea Mayes.

node.title: Modi says it will take India until 2070 to hit net zero emissions and asks for $1 trillion
node.description: The world's third-biggest greenhouse gas emitter has pledged net zero emissions by 2070, decades beyond what scientists say is needed to avoid catastrophic climate change.

node.title: RBA concedes interest rates may lift sooner than 2024
node.description: The Reserve Bank has kept Australia's cash rate at the record low 0.1 per cent, for its 12th month in a row, but it has also abandoned one of its key COVID-19 stimulus measures.
